Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Dynamics and Control of Motion Coordination for Information Transmission in Groups

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The long-term goal of this CAREER project is to improve our understanding of information transmission in biological groups and apply this understanding to synthesize bio-inspired motion- coordination algorithms for autonomous vehicles. How do schooling fish respond collectively to an external stimulus that is perceived by only a few individuals? How might we enable a fleet of autonomous vehicles to coordinate their movement using only sensory perception? In pursuit of this goal, the research objectives are (1) to use tools from estimation theory and computer vision to perform quantitative analysis of collective behavior in schooling fish; (2) to conduct laboratory experiments to test the hypothesis that schooling fish use motion coordination to amplify external signals and attenuate noise; (3) to construct an analytical modeling framework for information transfer in a kinetic interaction network; and (4) to synthesize bio-inspired motion-coordination algorithms using nonlinear-control tools.

The long-term educational goal of the PI is to cultivate an engaging environment for creative, rigorous application of dynamics and control theory that propels a diverse population of students to pursue STEM education and careers. In pursuit of this goal, the educational objectives are (1) to conduct K-12 outreach activities that broaden the STEM participation of minorities and women; (2) to pioneer a K-12 outreach framework that uses the topic of collective behavior in fish to create a partnership with a middle-school educator; and (3) to provide research experiences for aerospace undergraduate students.

The broader significance and importance of the proposed research activities lie in the promise of improved understanding of collective behavior in biological groups and improved capacity to model and synthesize collective motion in engineered networks. Improved tools for tracking biological aggregations can be used to understand mosquito swarms in malarial regions; to monitor the role of krill swarms in carbon sequestration; and to assess the impact of bacterial aggregations on human disease processes. Research in biologically inspired coordination of unmanned systems has applications in the inspection of aging civil infrastructure; improved forecasts of hurricane intensity; and environmental monitoring of climate variability. It is not presently understood what motion coordination strategies yield fast and accurate information transmission in biological systems because sufficient data to quantitatively analyze and model three-dimensional motion in large groups are not available. The proposed fish-tracking research will yield new tools for automated, three-dimensional trajectory reconstruction of the position, orientation, and shape of individual fish in a high-density school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied collective behavior in fish and its applications in cooperative control of undersea vehicles. We filmed fish using high frame-rate video in order to quantify their schooling behavior, particularly in response to visual threats. We created mathematical models of these responses in order to describe them in ways that might translate to other fields of research, such as engineering and robotics. A fleet of robotic submarines was created and multi-vehicle control was demonstrated in a laboratory environment.

A key research outcome of the project was an automated 3D tracking framework for studying animal aggregations. Designed for studying collective behavior in fish, the framework has subsequently been applied to study swarming and mating behavior in malarial mosquitoes, and thereby advanced the PI's long-term career goal of studying collective behavior in fish, insects, and other natural systems. A description of the tracking system has been published, and it has been used to generate at least two subsequent publications.

A second research outcome of this project is the synthesis of a probabilistic model for information transmission in animal groups based on experimental findings from the collective startle response of schooling fish. The model is currently being used to characterize the level of internal (to the school) interactions in schooling fish subjected to an artificial looming stimulus. The finding, which was unexpected, is that schooling fish in flowing water appear to rely less on internal signaling, perhaps because of saturation of the their hydrodynamic sense, which is used for both intra-school signaling and swimming/navigation.

The project has made educational achievements through its focus on training and diversity in outreach activities. More than 20 UMD undergraduate, masters, and doctoral students have been trained under this grant. The PI has worked with the Center of Minorities in the Clark School of Engineering at UMD to supervise the research internships of multiple high school and undergraduate students in the ESTEEM and LSAMP programs. Futhermore, with the help of the PI's graduate student Amanda Chicoli and former postdoc Nina Mahmoudian, the PI has lead two Women in Engineering LEAD Academy programs for middle and high school students. The PI's laboratory annually presents demonstrations to the general public during Maryland Day and Robotics Day at UMD.
